title: <italic>MicroRNA-203</italic> represses selection and expansion of oncogenic <italic>Hras</italic> transformed tumor initiating cells
abstract: In many mouse models of skin cancer, only a few tumors typically form even though many cells competent for tumorigenesis receive the same oncogenic stimuli. These observations suggest an active selection process for tumor-initiating cells. Here, we use quantitative mRNA- and miR-Seq to determine the impact of <italic>Hras</italic><sup>undefined</sup> on the transcriptome of keratinocytes. We discover that <italic>microRNA-203</italic> is downregulated by <italic>Hras</italic><sup>undefined</sup>. Using a knockout mouse model, we demonstrate that loss of <italic>microRNA-203</italic> promotes selection and expansion of tumor-initiating cells. Conversely, restoration of <italic>microRNA-203</italic> using an inducible model potently inhibits proliferation of these cells. We comprehensively identify <italic>microRNA-203</italic> targets required for <italic>Hras</italic>-initiated tumorigenesis. These targets include critical regulators of the <italic>Ras</italic> pathway and essential genes required for cell division. This study establishes a role for the loss of <italic>microRNA-203</italic> in promoting selection and expansion of <italic>Hras</italic> mutated cells and identifies a mechanism through which <italic>microRNA-203</italic> antagonizes <italic>Hras</italic>-mediated tumorigenesis.
